Key Features
Basic Rules
Gameplay Flow

What is Ultimate Frisbee: Ultimate Frisbee (often simply called Ultimate) is a fast-paced, non-contact team sport played with a flying disc (frisbee). It combines elements of soccer, football, and basketball, with the goal being to score points by catching the disc in the opposing team's end zone. It emphasizes sportsmanship, fair play, and teamwork.

Ultimate Frisbee - Complation

  1. Key Features
    • Teams: Typically played between two teams of 7 players each (indoor versions may have fewer players).
    • Field: The game is played on a rectangular field, usually 64 meters long and 37 meters wide, with two end zones (18 meters deep).
    • Starting Play: The game starts with a "pull" (a throw-off) from one team to the other.
    • Objective: The primary goal is to score points by catching the disc in the opposing team's end zone, similar to the end zones in football or rugby.
  2. Basic Rules
    • Movement: Players cannot run with the disc; they must establish a pivot foot and throw the disc to teammates to advance it down the field
    • Turns: When a pass is dropped, intercepted, or thrown out of bounds, possession of the disc is turned over to the other team.
    • Scoring: A point is scored when a player catches the disc in the opposing team's end zone.
    • Non-contact: Physical contact between players is not allowed. A "foul" occurs if a player is physically contacted or if the throw is illegal (e.g., traveling).
    • Substitutions: Players can substitute in and out between points but cannot during a point in progress.
  3. Gameplay Flow
    • Pull: A "pull" (throw-off) begins each point, where one team throws the disc to the other to start play.
    • Passing: Players pass the disc to each other, moving it down the field.
    • Defense: The defending team tries to block, intercept, or prevent passes.
    • Scoring: The offensive team attempts to catch the disc in the opposing end zone for a point.
    • Turnovers: If the offensive team fails to complete a pass (due to a drop, interception, or out-of-bounds), the defense takes possession.
